title: Kyle Schwarber’s massive home run symbolic of Chicago Cubs’ fun playoffs ride
text:
How many dragons did the Cubs slay Tuesday night?
Well, first there was the evil Cardinal, a vicious bird of prey from down South that left Chicago plucked and barely able to migrate.
The Cubs whipped their nemesis 6-4 in this deciding game of the National League Division Series, and historic feathers were everywhere. The Cardinals had the best record in the majors this season, don’t forget. One hundred wins, and bye-bye, birdie.
Think anybody wants to play these crazy Cubs right now? Not in baseball, my friend.
There was, too, the vanquishing of pitcher John Lackey, a mighty foe who was dominant in St. Louis’ Game 1 win.
Going on three days rest was noble. But in the end Lackey’s four earned runs in just three innings of work — including a stunning three-run home run to sub Javy Baez — made him just so much more road kill on the Cubs’ march to relevance and beyond.
What else?
Well, the idea that you can’t win with rookies and young guys was slain dead as a shingle.
At last glance, Cubs Kris Bryant, Jorge Soler (oh, what a gorgeous throw home he made in the sixth inning to nail a Cardinals baserunner!), Kyle Schwarber, Baez and the injured Addison Russell are young guys. Anthony Rizzo and Starlin Castro aren’t what you’d call old, either.
Then there is the idea that you can’t have fun if you’re dedicated to winning. The Cubs couldn’t have more fun if they were tied up and tickled.
Champagne blasting all over the place, with disco lights and plastic sheets everywhere, has become a Cubbie signature move. The joyous party last night that started immediately after Cubs pitcher Hector Rondon struck out Stephen Piscotty for the last out in the ninth inning ballooned to the pitchers mound, then into the clubhouse, then back onto the field like a living blob.
There were ski goggles, silly hats, and, then…cigars.
Blue smoke wafted from the stogies of relief pitcher Fernando Rodney and pals, drifting over the onfield scene like mustard gas (that is, if you don’t like cigar smoke).
What were they? From Cuba? From the Dominican Republic, like Rodney?
The man with the bleached blond top fuzz, one of the eight pitchers who helped the Cubs win this game, shrugged. Somebody handed them out, he said.
“It’s nice.’’
That’s an excellent phrase to describe this Cubs reversal of so much bad fortune from the past. Indeed, this current winning streak — 49-19, counting the playoffs, since July 29 — is almost hallucinatory in its heft. This wasn’t supposed to be the Cubs’ year. It was supposed to be next year, or the year after. Like always.
But now it’s upon us, and the Cubs have moved on to the National League Championship Series, which is so close to the promised land as to be almost terrifying.
But then so was 22-year old Kyle Schwarber’s mighty home run blast in the seventh inning. That ball sailed up and out of our sight and apparently went over the massive Budweiser video board in right field.
The muscular, squat left-handed-hitting Schwarber — can we call him mini-Ruth? — destroyed the pitch to the extent that if somebody said the ball simply exploded and vanished — well, you’d have to listen to that person.
“It went over the board,’’ said manager Joe Maddon afterward, looking toward the direction of Sheffield Ave. “I thought it did.’’
“We were all looking straight at it,’’ said Joe’s dad, Greg, who was seated in the lower grandstand with family, “and I don’t where it went.’’
“I think it did,’’ said Bryant when asked if the ball cleared that 50-foot tall barrier some 370 feet from home plate.
Good Lord.
“It’s been a crazy ride,’’ said Schwarber of his ascent from college ball to this level in less than a year.
His homer was a crazy ride, too — one that he actually called, Babe Ruth-style. Good Lord, again.
“Yeah. I said (to teammate Dexter Fowler), ‘I’m going to hit a home run off this guy.’ And he’s like, ‘Well, do it!’ There you go.’’
There we go. There it went.
And here come, at last, the Cubs.
